children.name: when you have the chance to do sth
chance
children.definition: a time or situation which you can use to do something that you want to doSYN opportunity
examples: chance (for sb) to do something
‘Back to School Night’ will be a chance for parents to meet their child’s teacher.
Ralph was waiting for a chance to introduce himself.
chance of
our only chance of escape
I’m sorry, I haven’t had a chance to look at it yet.

children.name: get/have a chance to do something
examples: I’d like a job in which I get the chance to travel.

children.name: give somebody/offer/provide a chance
examples: I was given the chance to play the main part in the play.|Sport provides a chance for you to get outside with friends.

children.name: take a chance
children.definition: accept an opportunity
examples: If I was offered the chance to be in the team, I’d take it.

children.name: jump at a chance
children.definition: use an opportunity eagerly
examples: Ed jumped at the chance to earn some extra money.

children.name: grab/seize a chance
children.definition: quickly use an opportunity
examples: As soon as she stopped speaking, I grabbed the chance to leave.

children.name: miss/lose a chance
children.definition: not use an opportunity
examples: He missed a chance to score just before half time.

children.name: throw away/pass up/turn down a chance
children.definition: not accept or use an opportunity
examples: Imagine throwing up a chance to go to America!

children.name: welcome the chance to do something
examples: I’d welcome the chance to discuss the problem with someone.

children.name: deserve a chance
examples: Every kid deserves a chance in life.

children.name: blow a chanceinformal
children.definition: have a special opportunity and fail to use it
examples: He thought he’d blown his chance of happiness.

children.name: a second chance/another chance
examples: The interview went badly, so I didn’t think they would give me a second chance.

children.name: sb’s last chance
examples: This is my last chance to try and pass the exam.

children.name: the chance of a lifetime
children.definition: one that you are very unlikely to have again
examples: If you don’t decide soon, you’ll have missed the chance of a lifetime.

children.name: now’s your chancespoken
children.definition: you have the opportunity to do something now
examples: You’re not working so now’s your chance to write a book.

children.name: given the chance/given half a chance
children.definition: if there is an opportunity to do something
examples: Goats will eat anything, given half a chance.

children.name: opportunity
children.definition: a chance to do something, especially something that isimportantor useful to you, or something that you want to do very much:
examples: opportunity for
Games and songs provide an opportunity for classroom interaction.
opportunity (for sb) to do something
a rare opportunity to see inside this historic building
I’d like to take this opportunity to thank you all.
We see this as an exciting opportunity for our companies to work together.
opportunity of doing something
After they had refused him the opportunity of improving his position, he resigned
a rare/unique opportunitya unique opportunity to stay in a real castle

children.name: have opportunity
examples: I was lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel.

children.name: take/use opportunity
children.definition: do something you have a chance to do
examples: Several employees took the opportunity to retire early.

children.name: seize/grasp an opportunity
children.definition: do something very eagerly when you have the chance
examples: She saw an opportunity to speak to him, and seized it.

children.name: miss/lose an opportunity
children.definition: not do something you have a chance to do
examples: Dwyer never missed an opportunity to criticize her.

children.name: give somebody opportunity
examples: The children should be given the opportunity to make their own choices.

children.name: get an opportunity
examples: I decided to go, as I might never get this opportunity again.

children.name: provide/present/open up an opportunity
examples: The course also provides an opportunity to study Japanese.

children.name: an opportunity comes
children.definition: along/up
examples: We had outgrown our house when the opportunity came up to buy one with more land.

children.name: an opportunity arises
examples: Perhaps she would explain later, if the opportunity arose.

children.name: a good/great/wonderful etc opportunity
examples: It's a great opportunity to try new things.

children.name: the ideal/perfect opportunity
examples: I'd been wanting to try sailing, and this seemed like the ideal opportunity.

children.name: a golden opportunity
children.definition: a very good opportunity
examples: The council has missed a golden opportunity to improve the town centre.

children.name: a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity
children.definition: a very good opportunity that you will only get once
examples: For many athletes, the Olympics are a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

children.name: a wasted/lost/missed opportunity
children.definition: one you do not use
examples: Many people see the failed talks as a missed opportunity for peace.

children.name: ample opportunity/plenty of opportunity
children.definition: a number of chances to do something
examples: There will be ample opportunity for shopping.

children.name: limited/little opportunity
children.definition: not many chances
examples: They had little opportunity to discuss the issue beforehand.

children.name: a photo opportunity
children.definition: a chance to take a good photograph, especially of a particular person
examples: Parents will always look for good photo opportunities at their kid's graduation ceremony.

children.name: at the first/earliest opportunity
children.definition: as soon as possible
examples: He decided to leave school at the earliest opportunity.

children.name: at every
children.definition: possible
examples: opportunity(= whenever possible )She went to the museum at every opportunity.

children.name: a window of opportunity
children.definition: a time when you can do something
examples: The other team started making mistakes, but we didn't take advantage of this window of opportunity.

children.name: a land of opportunity
children.definition: a country where people have a lot of good opportunities
examples: America was then seen as a land of opportunity.

children.name: the opportunity of a lifetime
children.definition: a very good opportunity that you will only get once
examples: The winner of the contest got the opportunity of a lifetime – the chance to work with a top fashion designer.

children.name: possibility U
children.definition: possibility  the chance to do something
examples: khả năng, tiềm năng
possibility for
khả năng, tiềm năng về
▪ The possibilities for improvement are endless.
Tiềm năng về sự phát triển là vô hạn.
▪ We need to investigate all possibilities for helping these children.
Chúng ta cần nghiên cứu mọi khả năng có thể để giúp những trẻ em này.

children.name: break
children.definition: a sudden or unexpected chance to do something, especially to be successful in your job: cơ hội, dịp tốt
examples: Gary wants to work in television. He’s just waiting for a break.
There are hundreds of young musicians out there looking for their first break.

children.name: lucky break
examples: Seeing that advertisement in the paper was a lucky break for me.

children.name: big break
examples: Nimoy’s big break in television came in the mid-'60s, when he won the role of Spock on ‘Star Trek’.
He got his firstbig breakin 1998.

children.name: room
children.definition: a chance to do things you want to do, in the way that you want to do them: cơ hội, dip tốt
examples: He refused the post because he felt it didn’t offer him much scope.

children.name: room for doubt/debate/argument etc
examples: The evidence was clear, and there was little room for doubt.

children.name: room for manoeuvreBritish Englishroom for maneuverAmerican English(= the possibility of changing what you do or decide )
examples: Teachers feel they have little room for manoeuvre when the curriculum is so demanding.

children.name: room for
examples: There’slittleroomfor innovation.

children.name: There will always be room for debate and disagreement in this class
examples: I have two jobs, which doesn’t leave much room for socializing.

children.name: room to do something
examples: Children need tohave roomto develop their natural creativity.
Make roomin your day for exercise.
We’ve left the course deliberately vague, so there’s room to concentrate on your particular areas of interest.
Better paid labour means greater scope to increase the company’s profits.

children.name: prospects
children.definition: chances of future success, especially at work: triển vọng
examples: I had no job, no education, andno prospects.
job/career prospects
Job prospects for graduates don’t look good.
Employers are now offering more jobs with quality training and excellent career prospects
prospects for
The prospects for an alliance between the two nations do not look good.

children.name: open doors U
children.definition: open doors for/open the door for   to give someone an opportunity to do something, for example the opportunity to do a particular job:

children.name: mở ra cánh cửa cơ hội
examples: ▪ My experience in the Peace Corps really opened doors for me when I started looking for a job.
Kinh nghiệm ở Tổ chức Hòa bình thật sự mở ra cánh cửa cho tôi trong tìm kiếm việc làm.
▪ Alice Coachman’s Olympic success opened the door for generations of African-American track athletes.
Thành công tại Olympic của Alice Coachman đã mở ra những cơ hội mới cho thế hệ vận động viên người Mỹ gốc Phi.

children.name: scope
children.definition: a chance to develop sth.Scopeis more formal thanroom: cơ hội, dịp tốt

children.name: scope for
examples: The scope for successful gardening increases dramatically with a greenhouse.

children.name: there is considerable/great/little etc scope for something
examples: There is considerable scope for further growth in the economy.

children.name: room/scope to do something
examples: Better paid labour means greater scope to increase the company’s profits.

children.name: to not get sth you could get
lose out
children.definition: to not get sth such as a job, contract etc because it is given to sb else instead: thua thiệt
examples: It’s simple -- unless you make an effort you’re going to lose out.

children.name: lose out to
examples: In the end we lost out to a French company because they could do the job cheaper.

children.name: lose out on
examples: Time and time again, women seem to lose out on promotions and career opportunities.

children.name: miss out
children.definition: to not get sth or be able to enjoy sth because you are not in the right place to do this: bỏ lỡ
examples: Where were you last night? You missed out.

children.name: miss out on
examples: She was so busy studying at university that she missed out on all the fun.
Get to the sales early to avoid missing out on all the best bargains.
If you don’t come to the picnic you’ll miss out on all the fun.
I don’t want to be the type of father who is so busy he misses out on his daughter’s childhood.

children.name: pass sb by
children.definition: if a chance or enjoyable experience passes you by, you do not get it because you do not make an effort or pay enough attention to it:
examples: Sometimes I feel that all the best things in life are passing me by.
Seize opportunities while you can - don’t let them pass you by.
He ended up a bitter old man who felt that life had somehow passed him by.

children.name: take the opportunity
children.definition: take the opportunity to do somethingnắm bắt cơ hội
examples: ▪ I would like to take this opportunity to thank you all for your help.

children.name: take the opportunity of doing something
examples: ▪ I’m going to take every opportunity of going to see Brian while he’s living in Germany.

children.name: grab the chance
children.definition: toquicklyuse an opportunity to do something, especially when you think you might not get another chance: chộp lấy cơ hội
examples: ▪ It may be the last time he offers you the job so I’d grab the chance while you can.

children.name: grab the chance to do something
examples: ▪ Knowing how difficult it is to find a job I grabbed the chance to be trained as an electrician.

children.name: jump at the chance
children.definition: /opportunity toeagerlyandquicklyuse an opportunity to do something: chộp lấy cơ hội
examples: ▪ The early retirement plan is excellent and I’m surprised that people haven’t jumped at the opportunity.

children.name: jump at the chance/opportunity to do something
examples: ▪ When the resort was put up for sale, the Millers jumped at the chance to buy it.
▪ She thought Lewis would jump at the opportunity to make some extra money on weekends.

children.name: jump at the chance/opportunity of doing something
examples: ▪ Who wouldn’t jump at the chance of spending a month in Australia?

children.name: strike while the iron is hot
children.definition: to do sth quickly, while you are in a situation in which you are most likely to be successful: tận dụng cơ hội
examples: Don’t wait until tomorrow before you tell him, strike while the iron is hot!

children.name: make hay while the sun shines
children.definition: to take the opportunity to do sth now while the conditions are good, because you might not be able to do it later: tranh thủ cơ hội
examples: Let’s make hay while the sun shines and finish this project before I start falling asleep.

children.name: miss a chance
children.definition: /an opportunity

children.name: miss a chance/an opportunity of
examples: Denise never misses the chance of a free meal.

children.name: miss a chance/an opportunity to do something
examples: Don’t miss this great opportunity to fly for half price.
Dan never misses an opportunity to remind me that I still owe him money.

children.name: miss your chance/opportunity
examples: Jerry’s already sold the car to someone else. You’ve missed your chance.

children.name: blow your chance
children.definition: blow it/ informalto waste a chance that you had to do or get something good:
examples: lãng phí/ tuột mất cơ hội
▪ Don’t panic and talk too much in the interview or you’ll really blow it.
Đừng hoảng sợ hay nói quá nhiều trong buổ phỏng vấn, bằng không bạn sẽ lãng phí mất cơ hội.
▪ I was afraid I’d blown my chance but she agreed to go out again on Saturday night.
Tôi sợ sẽ lãng phí mất cơ hội nhưng cô ấy đã đồng ý có buổi hẹn tiếp vào tối thứ bảy.
blow your chances of doing something
lãng phí cơ hội làm việc gì đó
▪ She started running much too fast at the beginning and blew her chances of winning the race.
Cô ấy chạy quá nhanh lúc bắt đầu và đã tuột mất cơ hội thắng đường đua.

children.name: miss the boat
children.definition: to be too late to use an opportunity to do sth good: bỏ lỡ cơ hội
examples: Buy your shares in the company now or you’ll miss the boat.
He didn’t get his application in early enough so he missed the boat.

children.name: let sth slip through your fingers
children.definition: to not use a good opportunity when you are able to, especially an opportunity that you will not get again: để vuột khỏi tầm tay
examples: We had an opportunity to win the championship last season and we let it slip through our fingers.

children.name: opportunist
children.definition: sb who always looks for and takes opportunities that might make them more successful: kẻ cơ hội
examples: It is difficult to tell whether he really wants to help May or whether he is just an opportunist.
As the finance company started to fail a few opportunists managed to make more money out of it.

children.name: turn
children.definition: nounTIME TO DO STH
examples: [ C ] an opportunity or a duty to do something at a particular time or in a particular
order, before or after other people
_Is it my turn yet?
_[ + to infinitive ]I waited so long for my turntosee the careers adviser that I missed my train.
_It's your turntodo the washing up!
_In this game if you give the wrong answer you have tomissa turn.

children.name: get
children.definition: verbgetting,got,got orUSgottenHAVE CHANCE
examples: [ I + to infinitive ]
to have the chance to do something
_I never gettosee her now that she's left the company.

children.name: gap in the market
children.definition: an opportunity for a product or service that does not already exist
examples: _There is a gap in the magazine market that needs to be filled.

children.name: platform
children.definition: nounIDEAS
